The Museum is closed on July 4 (Independence Day), July 24 (Pioneer Day), Thanksgiving Day, and Christmas Eve, Christmas Day, and New Year’s Day. (Early closure (3 pm) on New Year’s Eve.)

## Directions

### Parking

  * Metered parking is readily available on West Temple and 100 South between West Temple and Main Street.
  * Free: The first 2 hours of parking at City Creek Center Mall are free.
  * Paid parking is available at the Marriott Hotel across the street on West Temple.
  * Paid parking is available at the Plaza Hotel across the street on South Temple near the TRAX station.

### TRAX

Take Trax! When you depart from the Temple Square Station, we’re less than half a block from the station on West Temple.

### Bike

Ride a bike! There is ample bike parking in front of the Museum.

# Jude Agboada: Hu m’ani so ma me

Jan 16, 2026 – Mar 21, 2026

Overview Events

### Jump to

↓

Overview Events

[← All Exhibitions](/exhibitions)

AIR Space

Lower Level

Open today 11am–6pm

Suggested donation $10

Jude Agboada’s exhibition examines the enduring structures of colonialism through the lens of Ghana’s post-independence history. Although Ghana was among the first African nations to gain independence from British rule in 1957, Agboada approaches independence not as a conclusion but as a condition shaped by colonialism’s afterlives—its persistence within language, culture, architecture, and systems of representation.

The exhibition takes its title from a Ghanaian proverb,  _Hu m’ani so ma me, nti na atwe mmienu nam_ , translated from Akan as “antelopes walk in pairs to blow dust from each other’s eyes.” While the proverb is commonly associated with collaboration and mutual care, Agboada uses it as a critical metaphor. Seeing clearly, he suggests, is never a solitary act. In the context of colonial histories, the proverb resists singular or authoritative viewpoints, instead foregrounding collective witnessing, shared responsibility, and the necessity of multiple perspectives in the production of knowledge.
